title: Credible Intervals in Bayesian Statistics
contentHtml:
Credible intervals are a fundamental concept in Bayesian statistics that provide a range of values within which a parameter is likely to lie.

In frequentist statistics, confidence intervals are used to estimate population parameters. However, credible intervals offer a more nuanced approach by incorporating prior knowledge and updating it based on the data.

subject: statistics
title: Credible Intervals in Bayesian Statistics
contentHtml:
In Bayesian statistics, credible intervals provide a way to quantify uncertainty around a parameter estimate. Unlike frequentist confidence intervals, which are based on repeated sampling, credible intervals reflect the posterior distribution of the parameter.

Given a prior distribution and data likelihood, we can compute the posterior distribution using Bayes' theorem. The credible interval is then defined as the region within which the true value of the parameter has a certain probability (usually 95%) of lying.
whyMatters: Credible intervals are essential in Bayesian statistics because they provide a more accurate representation of uncertainty than frequentist confidence intervals. This is particularly important in machine learning and AI applications, where the choice of prior distribution can significantly impact the results.
intuition: Think of credible intervals as a range within which the true value of the parameter is likely to lie, given the data and our prior beliefs.
realWorldApplications: In Bayesian linear regression, credible intervals for coefficients provide a more nuanced understanding of their uncertainty.
commonMistakes: Confusing frequentist confidence intervals with Bayesian credible intervals

subject: statistics
title: Credible Intervals in Bayesian Statistics
contentHtml:
In Bayesian statistics, credible intervals provide a way to quantify uncertainty around a posterior distribution. Unlike frequentist confidence intervals, which are based on repeated sampling and population parameters, credible intervals reflect the uncertainty inherent in the data itself.

Given a posterior distribution p(θ|D) for some parameter θ, a credible interval is an interval [a, b] such that the probability of θ falling within this interval, given the data D, is at least 1-α.
intuition: Think of credible intervals as a way to summarize the uncertainty in your posterior distribution. They provide a range of values that are plausible given the data, rather than trying to pinpoint a single 'true' value.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, credible intervals can be used to quantify uncertainty in model predictions or hyperparameter tuning.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse credible intervals with frequentist confidence intervals; they have different interpretations and uses.

solutionHtml:
To find the posterior distribution, we can use Bayes' theorem:

\[ p(\mu | \mathbf{x}) = rac{p(\mathbf{x} | \mu) \cdot p(\mu)}{\int p(\mathbf{x} | \mu) \cdot p(\mu) d\mu }.\]

Since the prior is conjugate to the likelihood, we can use a normal distribution with mean \(0\) and variance \( rac{1}{k}\sigma^2\) as our prior.

The posterior distribution will also be normal, with mean:

The 95% credible interval will be the 2.5th and 97.5th percentiles of this distribution.
